first_story_block:
You button up your jacket and silently curse the jerk who decided zippers aren’t cultured enough. The wind shifts between violent gusts and a gentle breeze. Almost no one plays outside today. The overcast skies and bare trees seem foreboding. The warmth of the school halls and brightness from artificial lighting seem much more inviting.

That’s why you’re out here, because they’re inside. You deemed the pool too crowded and the dorms too wild. On the average dreary Saturday, half the boys receive warnings while a couple dozen are punished, not that it really matters. As long as their parents send in enough money, the troublemakers stay.

You pick up a rock from the path. You toss it up and catch it a few times. Then, you hurl the rock into the woods. It soars until it makes a resounding thunk against a limb. A bird flies away chirping out a warning, so you cringe. “Sorry,” you say under your breath. Of course, the bird doesn’t hear it, but it makes you feel a little better.

The wind gusts again and you shiver, though it’s not as bad as last time. You should’ve brought your hat, but you were in a rush to get out here. No one strolls through the woods despite the nice scenery and rock path. You shrug at people’s indifference towards plain beauty, trees on a frigid winter day.

You cross your arms until the wind dies down. In this moment, you hear nothing. No fellow classmates chattering about whatnot, no teachers lecturing about the lessons, and no Cerise annoying you for fun.

Then, the silence ends with a faint, feminine whimper. You strain your ears to find the source. Who’d be out here anyway? You follow the sound off the path and to a small grove of pines. Looking around, you don’t see anyone, just the green needles, grey sky, and brown ground covered in leaves. You step on a twig, and the whimpering stops.

“Hello?” you ask. “Is everything alright? Are you hurt?”

No one responds. Was the sound only the wind? It couldn’t be. Someone was crying.

You walk around the clearing and check behind the trees. Peering behind a large pine tree, you see flowing red hair. You gulp and kneel in front of the girl. Though her hair obscures her face, you still see a scowl and tears falling to the ground.

“Cerise?” You ask, afraid of what may come next from your tormentor.
She doesn’t bother looking up. “Get lost.”

action_results.result:
Cerise’s an inch shorter than you, though you’ll be even taller soon. She has a voice that can project across a soccer field. Other than you, she’s the best pianist in middle school. Never once have you seen her cry, until now. She looks like a little girl, not the fiery young teen that you know.

“Um, are you hurt?” You get off your knees and sit on the frozen ground.
“What do you think?” She shoots her right arm forward at you face. You move back, expected to be punched. She stops an inch away and shoves her wrist brace in your face. “It’s a minor sprain, but some jerk ratted me out to the dang nurse.”

She wipes away her tears with her good hand and crosses her arms. “She freaked and friggen' banned me from playing piano. Then, she told the manager of the talent show that I can’t use my right hand. How can I play the piano with only my left hand! You can’t, and she knows it. She did it just to spite me. I saw her smile.”

Then, she looks up. Her eyes are reddened from her crying. Her checks turned cherry from the cold, and her teeth chatter. Only now do you realize that she doesn’t have her jacket on, just her schoolgirl uniform.

“What the heck are you still doing here? Scram.” Out of habit, she punches you with her right arm. It’s not hard; it never is, but her eyes widen in pain at the moment of contact. “Crap!” She shakes her wrist as if it could fling off the sting. “Dang pain.”

You unbutton your jacket. “Here,” you say while taking it off. “Take this.”

She snatches it from your hand and mumbles a thanks. She puts it on. For the next minute, neither of you say anything. You just hear her breathing, the wind, and a bird chirping overhead.

You mind wanders around. You’ve known her for how long? Two years? That entire time, she never cried. Two black eyes from a brawl, getting an F in her favorite subject, those nasty rumors spread by some girls. No tears.

You scratch your head. Now, she’s crying about a talent show? She never bothered entering in the other annual ones. Though, for the past few weeks, she’s been raving about it. Maybe she sees it as a rare opportunity to show off to adults? Cerise likes to show off, a lot.

More memories of her spring up. You try to push them away, but you can’t.

Memories are a funny thing. Sometimes, you remember the most vivid details, the taste of apple pie or the sting of a wasp. Other times, it’s just a blur.

For instance, you can’t remember why you didn’t study for the math test. Mr. Lawrence warned you to study too. What was so important? Funny. Since you can’t remember, maybe it wasn’t.

Most of the students were in the class already, waiting for the teacher to arrive. You were fidgeting and drying your sweaty hands off on your pants over and over again. Then, you feel a sharp poke on your shoulder. That sensation has remained clear in your mind.

What did Cerise say? It went something like, “What’s up?”

You told her that you didn’t study and you needed a good grade. So, she humphs and makes some witty remark. You remember only one other thing before the teacher arrived. You tried to sink into your seat as if it could make you disappear. Then, Mr. Lawrence entered and handed out the tests. Only half the questions made sense to you.

After filling out what you could, you scribbled answers onto the other ones. At least one of those had to be right. If you guessed correctly, then maybe you could've revived a D. You heard three slight taps from your left. You glanced over and saw Cerise tap one last time on a question, an answered question. You looked back at your test. You guessed the answer to that one, so you copy down her answer.

Out of the corner of your eye, you saw her erase a nine and write another nine in its place. That was another answer you didn’t get right. She helped you two more times before the test ended. Instead of an F, you received a C. She spent so much time helping you out that she forgot to complete the last question. It ended up being her only B in math that semester.

You never did thank her for that.

“Cerise?” you asks.
“What?”
“Is there anything I can do to help?”
“Can you heal sprained wrists? If not, then a massive no.”

You sigh. Something’s very wrong. You need to find out.

“What piece were you going to perform?”
“It doesn’t matter now.” She turns away from you.
“It does to me.”
“You’re so sappy.” She sounds a bit happier. “Jesús bleibet meine Freude.”
You tilt your head. “Bach? I thought you were a Mozart girl?” She made fun of you before for playing Bach, yet she was going to do one for the talent show?
“I am.”
“Then why…”
“My father likes Bach.”

Your eyes open wide. That’s the first thing you ever heard her speak about her father. Her dead mother, yeah, she said a few things about her, but never her father.

She turns back to you. The scowl returns to her face. “Do you know how many times I saw my dad in the past two and a half years?”

You think for a moment. She lives on campus throughout the summer like you. Also like you, she almost never leaves either. You never saw her father before. Oh crap.

“Not once?”
She nods. “Yeah, fancy that. What type of idiot do you have to be to not once see your little girl? Well, this was my chance. I heard from Nancy that he’ll be in Albany this week, so I invited him to come in a letter. I told him I’d play Jesús bleibet meine Freude. My mom said that she performed it at their wedding, and my plan worked. He said he’d make it. He promised. Then, I fell down some stairs like a retard.”

Who’s Nancy? Maybe she’s her stepmom or her dad’s maid… something like that. Cerise doesn’t know any Nancy at the school.

You feel a tear form in your eye, but you wipe it away before she notices. She’d mock you for being a girly boy.

Poor Cerise. Now you know why she was crying. You should do… something. You’re friends, sorta.

“Screw your old man.”
“What?” She stands up, so you do too.
“You’re better than him. He doesn’t deserve to hear you play.”
“It’s not that simple.”

You sigh. She needs to get her mind off of this. It’s hurting her.

“You wanna go get some ice cream? I have two tickets that I never used.”
“Ice cream? I haven’t had… You’re trying to distract me!” She pokes you in the chest with her good hand. You take a step back.
“Cerise, yes! I am. Crying in the middle of the forest and freezing to death isn't good!”
Her eyes narrow. “If you ever tell anyone what you saw or heard out here, I’ll make you life a living hell!”
You hold up your hands as if it’s a sign of surrender. “I promise. I always keep my promises.”

She walks up to you and glares as if she’s making an analyses. You cringe but don’t back away from her violation of your personal space.

“Fine, but take this before we head back.” She hands you the jacket.
“You can keep it until we get inside.”
“Idiot, what will the gossip be when they see you and me walking out of the woods with me wearing your jacket?”
“Oh.”
“See you in fifteen minutes.”

She sprints down the trail. You shake your head. “Women,” you mumble under your breath. A cold breeze lofts through the forest again. You button up your jacket.

She sits on the other side of the table. Her red hair rests in a ponytail as she devours her cherry ice cream. Melted dessert covers her chin and the table since she’s using her left hand, but she doesn’t seem to care. You’ve only taken three bites from your vanilla.

“You feeling better?” you ask. She must’ve cleaned up her face before she arrived. There’s not a trace of her tears.
“Um, yeah,” she says between spoonfuls. When she finishes the last scoop, she gives a nervous smile. “Hey… Thanks.”
You smile back. “I’m glad to help.”
She looks down at your bowl. “Are you gonna eat that?”

You shake your head and pass it to her.

“Hey, do you remember that time you fought Dick?”
She chuckles. “And made a him barfing mess? Yup.”
“What caused the fight?”
She shakes her head. “No clue. Don’t remember.”
“Why didn’t you hide your black eyes for the photos?”

She stops eating. She carefully sets down her spoon and looks right at you. “School pictures are sent to your guardian.”
“Oh.” She wanted her father to see her injured. She tried to get his attention.

She looks down at her ice cream then back to you. She pushes the bowl to your side of the table. “You should have the rest.”

You nod. You eat the ice cream but don’t pay attention to the flavor. It won’t be something you remember. You’ll remember Cerise’s eyes. She’s staring at you with a look you haven’t seen before. You don’t know how to read it either. You feel your hands sweat.

When you finish, you both stand up from the table. Then, she holds out her left hand. You tilt your head in confusion.

“Shake it, dummy.”

You reach out with my left hand and shake hers. It’s warm. Her hand feels so warm. You both smile and flush a light red.

“I don’t think I’ve ever told you this,” she says still shaking your hand. “But you’re my friend.”
“You’re my friend too.”

You feel the gaze of others on us. She does too, so you let go.

“You wanna hang out tomorrow?” Her eyes look hopeful.
“Sure.”

“I’ll help you play.”
“Excuse me?”
“You can do half with your left hand. I’ll do the other half. That way, we can still enter.”
“That won’t work. The timing. We’ll have to be in sync. Plus, I’d have to play the right hand stuff with my left hand. And… And…”

She paces back and forth mumbling about the technical aspects. You think it’ll work. You did some duet stuff before, though no one has with Cerise. They’re all too scared and she’s too prideful.

“Are you sure you’d wanna do this?” she asks.
“Absolutely.”
“Then, let’s give it a shot.” She gives me a smile. “Meet me in the music hall in fifteen minutes, okay?”
“Sure.”

She runs off but stops. Then, she walks back to you. “Also, take this before we head back.” She hands you the jacket.
“You can keep it until we get inside.”
“Idiot, what will the gossip be when they see you and me walking out of the woods with me wearing your jacket?”
“Oh.”

She sprints down the trail. You shake your head. “I better not screw up,” you mumble under your breath. A cold breeze lofts through the forest again. You button up your jacket.

You step into the music hall. It’s old, older than anyone alive like the rest of the school. Bricks go up either wall mixed in with Greek architecture. In all honesty, you never liked the style. They say it’s cultured. You think it looks more like a ghetto White House.

Stored in cases and stacked in shelves, there’s hundreds of instruments here. Flutes, sitars, and maracas… The higher ups didn’t cheap out on anything, but you only care about one instrument, the grand piano. You walk to a dark corner of the hall. The high ceilings and small windows transform the school into a dungeon, but you don’t mind. It gives a cool atmosphere.

Cerise already sits at the grand piano. She’s on the right side of the seat, so you take the left one. You run your fingers over the keys, and it gives a dark sound. You’d prefer it brighter, but this’s the only one. The grand piano has a slightly brown tinge to its black exterior, and its sheer size gives the instrument a presence. When in the same room, it’s hard not to look at it at least once.

“Hey.” You smile at her.

She groans then points to the sheet music.

“I know this piece by heart,” you say.
She narrows her eyes in anger. “You should’ve told me that before I dug this up.”

She flings the papers off to the right. They drift in the air before lofting onto the floor. You’ll have to clean them up before you leave.

“Okay,” she says. “No metronome. I’ll just start, and you keep up. Got it?”
“Yeah.”

She places her left hand over the keys. She plays the music, and it sweeps you off your feet. Your head sways back and forth and you’re transported to a peaceful, beautiful land. You haven’t really listened to her play before. You’ve heard it, but you’ve never let it sweep you up like this.

Then, you're brought out of tranquility with a sharp jab.

“Ow!” You rub your chest. “Why’d you poke me?”
“You should be playing with me…” She looks at the keys and hunches her shoulders. “I’m sorry, okay? I’m stressed. This’s really nice of you though. Let’s try again, alright?” She apologized to you, odd.

She plays again, and this time you start.

You go again and again until the bells ring out. In this moment, other children get into their beds. You should’ve left thirty minutes ago to be ready in time. You stand up to leave, but Cerise grabs your wrist. She looks you in the eyes and asks, “A few more times, okay?”

You nod. It won’t be much longer.

Twenty minutes later, you yawn. For just one moment, you lose your concentration and her hand brushes against yours. She stops playing, so the room becomes silent. Your heart pounds in your ears.

She stands up, and you nearly fall out of the chair. “We should get going.”
You nod.
“I’ll see you tomorrow. Let’s be sure to meet up to practice.”
“Um, okay. Bye.”

She runs away. You shake your head. After putting her papers in a trash can, you look outside. If anyone would’ve checked, they’d have found you missing by now. There’s no point in rushing back to the dorm, but you could use some sleep.

You head back to the dorms. There’s a bunch of them, and they smell like sweaty socks, but the school makes you sleep there. You wind your way past the brick, archaic buildings trying to stay in the shadows. You shiver from the cold. Not one animal makes a sound.

“Taylor.” You freeze from the sound of his voice. “Turn around.”

You do. Mr. Lawrence gets up from a bench. You gulp. “I apologize, sir.” He's the only teacher who you like. He even calls you by your first name. No one else does that.

“What are you doing past curfew?” He doesn’t sound angry, just curious.
“I… I was helping a friend.”
“Doing what?” He stops a few feet from you.
“Practicing piano. She… she sprained her hand before the talent show, and I offered to do the left hand parts.”
“That was thoughtful, but you’re still out at night.”

You sigh. There’s no way you’re getting out of this. You’ll be suspended from activities for the next week. Cerise won’t have you to help her, and she needs your help.

“Sir?”
“Yes.”
“She really wants to perform, but she needs me to do the other half.”
“I already know that.”
“Don’t let her know I said this, but she’s doing it just to see her dad.”

He rubs his chin and nods. You look around to see if anyone else spotted you. They haven’t.

“Go on.”
“Really?”
“Just be there for Cerise.”
“How d-did you know?”
“Lucky guess. I heard her screaming at the nurse today. Goodnight.”

You both chuckle. Then, you walk away. You sneak into your dorm and get ready for bed. Tomorrow will be a big day.

Cerise kicks her legs back and forth. You both sit on a bench surrounded by other students. On stage, a sixth grader gets heckled by some kids in the audience, the poor idiot.

All of the students wear their school uniforms, but the girls prettied up their hair. Well, they tried to. Cerise told you there’s only so much a girl can do while using the allowed hair products. She has her hair back in a ponytail not wanting it to fall over her face during performance.

She glances at you but looks away when you make eye contact. She licks her lips and swallows.

She pokes your side, but you suppress yelping in pain. “Are you sure you’re ready?” she asks.
“Yes,” you say for the fifth time.
“Did you sleep enough?”
“Yes, though I met Mr. Lawrence on the way back to my dorms. He didn’t report me.”
“That’s nice of him.”
“Yeah. I think he’ll be out there.”

She nods. You’re gripped in an awkward silence again. You look at the list of entries. Cerise’s name sits under some guy named Erwin Brooks. Is that the kid on stage? Maybe. They’ll announce you to walk up anyway, so you shouldn’t worry about it.

You notice Cerise breathes faster. You need to calm her.

“Hey, remember that time you got into a fight with Dick? You got two black eyes somehow.”
“Yeah.”
“You're really tough. I'm sorry I didn't help you.”
“No, I wanted to get hurt. All parents get the school photos. I hoped that would've made him say something to me.”

Is that why she fought so much? Is that why the straight A student has her own chair in the principal's office? You'll need to do something about that. Not now, but soon. She shouldn't be doing all of that for her father.

“Taylor, thanks.” She smiles.

Before you could ask what she meant, you hear her name called up to stage. The announcer person explains your presence to the crowd.

Your heart pounds. Your vision focuses on nothing but Cerise and the piano. She sits down and closes her eyes. You lick your lips and take the spot next to her.

The first note emanates from the grand piano. Then, the second. You join on the third. You’re transported to a happy world, but this time you share it with Cerise. The music waltzes on by as you both walk on a green hill. The sun warms your skin. You stop by a creek and take of your shoes. She cools off her feet in the murmuring waters with you.

Then, the music stops. The crowd claps. You wish it would be an eruption of joyous sounds, but it’s just bored and polite. She takes your hand and leads you to the front of the stage.

You look at the swarm of people. Over two hundred men and women dressed in expensive suits and dresses just… sit and clap. Their faces look plastic, frozen in an artificial smile. The few children that you do see appear antsy At least the teachers look impressed, but you know that they’re surprised you and Cerise didn’t squabble on stage. At least Mr. Lawrence seems impressed. He gives both of you a thumbs up.

She raises your hand in the air with hers. You bow together. She leads you away. Once off stage, you open your mouth to speak, but she continues dragging you. She drags you away from the stage, down some halls, and out the building. Outside, she stops and turns around. Tears fall down her eyes.

“Cerise?”
“He wasn’t there.” She sniffles.

You cringe. That no good bastard of a father! How dare he abandon his daughter like that! What should you do? She’s standing there crying. Is she waiting for you to do something? Will she lash out if you do?

You take a step closer to her. She gasps as you wrap your arms around her. You feel her body relax. She rests her head on your shoulder and cries onto your shirt. Her arms rise up to your back and her hands hold onto your shoulders.

Her breathing slows down. What should you do now? You have no clue, so you stay there, not letting her go.

“Taylor?”
“Yes.”
“You went up there on stage. You spent so many hours yesterday practicing. Now, you’re still with me. Why?”
“We’re friends, remember?”
“Idiot.” Her tone lacks the usual venom. “Friends don’t hug like this for so long.”
“I won’t let you be abandoned.”
“I’ve never apologized for being so mean to you. Sorry. I think I still will, so sorry for that too.”
“It’s fine.”

Behind the auditorium, you both hug. Maybe it’s a minute later, maybe it’s an hour; however, you end the hug. She wipes away the tears from her eyes. Her lips curl up into a smile. You smile back.

“If you tell anyone what just happened…” she says.
“Yeah,” you joke. “You’ll kill me.”

Both of you chuckle.

“You wanna see if we won?” You point back at the building.
“I don’t care about that. Let’s go do something else.” She motions to the school grounds. “Like what?”
“I’ll be with you. Right now, that’s what I want.”

You spend the rest of the day with Cerise. You talk, you laugh, and you play. It turns out to be the best day of both of your lives, one of many more to come.

“Friends.”

Her tears stop. She looks at you, in your eyes.

“I don’t know what to do now,” she confesses. You hear a small amount of fear in her tone.
“Come on. Let’s go.”
“Go where?”
“I’m not sure. Away from here. Somewhere for us.”
“Okay. I got an idea.”

She takes you by the hand. For some reason, the close contact doesn’t seem awkward anymore. She rushes down the path to wherever you’re both going. You don’t mind. There’s a joyful grin on her face. Right now, that’s all what matters to you.

You open the rickety gate and head inside. From what you remember, this’s one of the oldest parts of the school, maybe the oldest. So many names have died along with their owners. You stop in front of one. Edwin. Nice enough name, but it’s gone, like the owner.

You shiver. The wind blows icy gusts that get under your clothing and rip out what little warmth you have. You lean against the grave to shield against the weather.

“Hello.” Who said that?

You look around for the speaker. She sounded like a girl.

“Boo!” she says. You jump back and bang your head of the gravestone. “Oops, sorry.”

You rub your eyes. You’re gonna have a killer headache soon. When you open them, you see an outstretched hand. You grasp it, and she pulls you up.

“Ouch.” You shake your head a little as if it could fling off the pain.

“Um, I wasn’t planning to, but I am now.”
“Cool. Why?”
“My friend hurt her wrist, so I’m doing the other half for her. She… she really wanted to do it.”
“Personal reasons?”
“Yeah.”

You touch the back of your head again. Expecting at least some soreness, you feel noting. Well, you won’t complain. The clouds still obscure the moon, so you can’t see much of the girl.

“Great!” She sounds happy again.
“Will I see you at the talent show?”

“Sure. Will I see you again? Hey, what’s your name? I’m Taylor.”

You hold your hand out. She shakes it with vigor.

“You can call me Mag. I’ll be back when you graduate.” Huh, that’s funny. Today is… and that day is…

You cringe. That no good bastard of a father! How dare he abandon his daughter like that! What should you do? She’s standing there crying. Is she waiting for you to do something? Will she lash out if you do?

You take a step closer to her. She gasps as you wrap your arms around her. You feel her body relax. She rests her head on your shoulder and cries onto your shirt. Her arms rise up to your back and her hands hold onto your shoulders.

Her breathing slows down. What should you do now? You have no clue, so you stay there, not letting her go.

“Taylor?”
“Yes.”
“You went up there on stage. You spent so many hours yesterday practicing. Now, you’re still with me. Why?”
“We’re friends, remember?”
“Idiot.” Her tone lacks the usual venom. “Friends don’t hug like this for so long.”
“I won’t let you be abandoned.”
“I’ve never apologized for being so mean to you. Sorry. I think I still will, so sorry for that too.”
“It’s fine.”

Behind the auditorium, you both hug. Maybe it’s a minute later, maybe it’s an hour; however, you end the hug. She wipes away the tears from her eyes. Her lips curl up into a smile. You smile back.

“If you tell anyone what just happened…” she says.
“Yeah,” you joke. “You’ll kill me.”

Both of you chuckle.

“You wanna see if we won?” You point back at the building.
“I don’t care about that. Let’s go do something else.” She motions to the school grounds. “Like what?”
“I’ll be with you. Right now, that’s what I want.”

You spend the rest of the day with Cerise. You talk, you laugh, and you play. It turns out to be the best day of both of your lives, one of many more to come.

Neither you nor Cerise noticed the girl happily watching you, leaning on a gravestone.

action_results.action: Tell Her to Forget Her Father
action_results.result:
“Who needs him?” Anger seeps through your voice.
“What?” She takes out a tissue from her pocket and dries her tears.
“He didn’t show up. He doesn’t care about you, so let him rot away alone.”
“He’s all I got.”

She breaks down into sobbing again. How could that man do this to his own daughter? He doesn't care!

You place your hand on her shoulder. You care.

“I know I’m not much, but how about me?”
“Taylor, you’re just…”
“Now, I’m all you got.”
She smiles, a little. “That was so corny.”

She looks at your hand, the one resting on her shoulder. She takes that hand and shakes it.

“Friends?” she asks.
“Friends.”

Her tears stop. She looks at you, in your eyes.

“I don’t know what to do now,” she confesses. You hear a small amount of fear in her tone.
“Come on. Let’s go.”
“Go where?”
“I’m not sure. Away from here. Somewhere for us.”
“Okay. I got an idea.”

She takes you by the hand. For some reason, the close contact doesn’t seem awkward anymore. She rushes down the path to wherever you’re both going. You don’t mind. There’s a joyful grin on her face. Right now, that’s all what matters to you.

Neither you nor Cerise see the girl happily watching you, leaning on a gravestone.

You weren’t there when the fight broke out, and you don’t remember why it started. Knowing Cerise, she either thought that jerk… What was his name? Dick. How fitting. She either thought that Dick was ogling her too much or she was pestering him and he snapped. It doesn’t matter at this point. They were fighting.

You pushed through the crowd of students. Dick stood pretty tall for an eighth grader, and she was just a seventh grader at that time. He wasn’t pulling punches either. Blood poured down her lip and two nasty bruises formed around her eyes. You wanted to help her, you really did, but you hesitated for a moment. As it turns out, she didn’t need the help.

She glanced at you and smiled. Dick threw a wild punch that missed. His hand slammed into a locker and he screamed like a girl. She kneed him hard between his legs, and Dick reached a higher octave with his screaming. A teacher came up to stop the fight, but it was over. Dick squirmed on the ground puking on himself.

You ran to her side. “Let’s get to the nurse.” You offered her your hand. Why? It seemed polite.
“I can do it myself!” Before the teacher could stop her, she pushed through the swarm of students and stumbled to the nurse’s office.

Dick broke two fingers. Unofficially, those weren't the only part of Dick that broke.

The next day was school photos, and Cerise showed up with two black eyes and a swollen lip. She never bothered to hide it with makeup.

You don't do anything.

For the next minute, neither of you say anything. You just hear her breathing, the wind, and a bird chirping overhead.

You mind wanders around. You’ve known her for how long? Two years? That entire time, she never cried. Two black eyes from a brawl, getting an F in her favorite subject, those nasty rumors spread by some girls. No tears.

You scratch your head. Now, she’s crying about a talent show? She never bothered entering in the other annual ones. Though, for the past few weeks, she’s been raving about it. Maybe she sees it as a rare opportunity to show off to adults? Cerise likes to show off, a lot.

More memories of her spring up. You try to push them away, but you can’t.
